case_vignette:
A 21-year-old man comes to the physician because of pruritus and a hypopigmented rash on his upper body for 5 days. He first noticed the symptoms after returning from a business trip last week in the Bahamas. While he was there, he visited a couple of beaches and went hiking with some coworkers. The rash initially started as a single lesion on his upper back but since then has extended to his shoulders. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump. He works as an office manager and has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. He has been sexually active with three female partners over the past year and uses condoms inconsistently. He is 183 cm (6 ft) tall and weighs 80 kg (176 lb); BMI is 23.9 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. One month ago, his hemoglobin A1C was 7.8%. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis? A) Skin biopsy B) Blood tests for fungal infections C) D) E) Dapsone
Step 1: Identify the gender-specific references in the text.
The text contains the following gender-specific references:
- "A 21-year-old man"
- "He has been sexually active with three female partners"
- "He" is used repeatedly to refer to the patient

Step 2: Rewrite the text to remove the gender-specific references.

The rash initially started as a single lesion on the upper back but since then has extended to the shoulders. The patient has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with an insulin pump. The patient works as an office manager and has no known exposure to melanocytotoxic chemicals. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. I have itching and a light-colored rash on my upper body that started 5 days ago.

No, I don't have symptoms like fever, joint pain, or swelling.

No, I have not had similar skin issues in the past.

No information about my family's medical history regarding skin diseases or autoimmune conditions has been provided.

No, I haven't noticed any specific patterns to the itching like worsening at night or after sun exposure.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea Versicolor
